revisions.*:
{{other people|Richard Martin}} [[Image:Sir Richard Martin, 1st Baronet, of Overbury Court.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Martin in 1895.]] '''Sir Richard Biddulph Martin, 1st Baronet''' (12 May 1838 – 23 August 1916){{cite web | url = http://www.leighrayment.com/baronetage/baronetsM2.htm | title = Baronetcies beginning with "M" (part 2) | work = Leigh Rayment's Baronetage pages | accessdate = 2009-04-30 }} was an English banker and [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal Party]] (and later [[Liberal Unionist Party|Liberal Unionist]]) politician. Martin was the older of two sons of Robert Martin (1808–1897) of [[Overbury Court]] near [[Tewkesbury]] in [[Gloucestershire]] and his wife, Mary Ann (d. 1892), who was the daughter of John Biddulph of the banking firm of [[Cocks Biddulph|Cocks, Biddulph & Co]]. Robert Martin was a partner of the Grasshopper Bank, which later became [[Martins Bank]].Lawrence Goldman, ‘Woodhull, Victoria Claflin (1838–1927)’, [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/articleHL/98231 Oxford Dictionary of National Biography], online edn, Oxford University Press, Oct 2008 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/98231, accessed 1 May 2009] He was educated at [[Harrow School]] and at [[Exeter College, Oxford]], before joining his maternal grandfather's bank.{{cite book | last = Martin | first = John Biddulph | title = The Grasshopper in Lombard Street | publisher = Ayer Publishing | year = 1968 | origyear = 1892 | isbn=978-0-8337-2266-9 | url = http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6tTRQms7EW8C }} He later became one of the founders of the [[British North Borneo Company]] and of the [[Institute of Bankers]]. Martin first stood for election to the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1868|1868 general election]], when he was an unsuccessful candidate in the [[East Worcestershire (UK Parliament constituency)|Eastern division of Worcestershire]]. He was unsuccessful again in next candidacy, at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1880|1880 general election]] in the [[City of London (UK Parliament constituency)|City of London]].{{cite book |last=Craig |first=F. W. S. |authorlink= F. W. S. Craig |title=British parliamentary election results 1832–1885 |origyear=1977 |edition= 2nd |year=1989 |publisher= Parliamentary Research Services |location=Chichester |isbn= 0-900178-26-4 |pages=6, 304, 485 }} However, 3 months later he was elected as [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Tewkesbury (UK Parliament constituency)|Tewkesbury]] at a by-election held in July 1880 after the result of the general election in April was overturned on petition. Several of his ancestors had held the seat in the past, but Richard was the last Martin to represent Tewkesbury. The [[Parliamentary Borough]] of Tewkesbury was abolished under the [[Reform Act 1885]] and replaced with a wider [[county division]] of Gloucestershire. At the [[United Kingdom general election, 1885|1885 general election]], he did not stand for re-election in the new Tewkesbury division of Gloucestershire, contesting instead the [[Chelmsford (UK Parliament constituency)|Chelmsford division of Essex]], but without success.{{cite book |last=Craig |first=F. W. S. |authorlink= F. W. S. Craig |title=British parliamentary election results 1885–1918 |origyear=1974 |edition= 2nd |year=1989 |publisher= Parliamentary Research Services |location=Chichester |isbn= 0-900178-27-2 |pages=255, 275, 420 }} When the Liberal Party split over [[Irish Home Rule]], he joined the breakaway [[Liberal Unionist Party]], and stood as a Liberal Unionist in the [[Ashburton (UK Parliament constituency)|Ashburton division of Devon]], again without success. He finally returned to [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1892|1892 general election]] as MP for the [[Droitwich|Droitwich division of Worcestershire]], replacing the Liberal Unionist [[John Corbett (industrialist)|John Corbett]], who had retired. Martin remained Droitwich's MP until he stood down at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1906|1906 general election]]. He was made a [[baronet]] on 12 December 1905, of Overbury Court, in [[Gloucestershire]]. He died childless, and the title became extinct on his death. He was President of the [[Royal Statistical Society]] from 1906 to 1907.{{cite web|url=http://www.rss.org.uk/site/cms/contentviewarticle.asp?article=486|title=Past Presidents|work=Royal Statistical Society website|accessdate=2009-05-01}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Hansard-contribs | mr-richard-martin | Richard Martin }} * [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/nra/searches/subjectView.asp?ID=P19213 Richard Biddulph Martin] in the [[National Register of Archives]] {{s-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{succession box | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Tewkesbury (UK Parliament constituency)|Tewkesbury]] | years = [[Tewkesbury by-election, 1880|1880]] – [[United Kingdom general election, 1885|1885]] | before = [[William Edwin Price]] | after = [[John Reginald Yorke]] }} {{succession box | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Droitwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Droitwich]] | years = [[United Kingdom general election, 1892|1892]] – [[United Kingdom general election, 1906|1906]] | before = [[John Corbett (industrialist)|John Corbett]] | after = [[Cecil Harmsworth, 1st Baron Harmsworth|Cecil Harmsworth]] }} {{s-reg|uk-bt}} {{s-new | creation }} {{s-ttl | title = [[Martin Baronets|Baronet]]
